channel.title: Player Saves in my Java game
channel.description: Hello, right now I am making my first Java program, it is in cmd and its basically a Math game, but here is my question, I want to ask what the players name is and then save it according to what he enters, but idk how I would start, I have the class PlayerSaves made but I'm not entirely sure what to do... If you could explain to me how I should start this please let me know.

item.title: Player Saves in my Java game
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:21, topic:416588”][quote author=Arrav link=topic=518481.msg3773776#msg3773776 date=1317932248]
Wow buffered reader is another way for someone to steal your accounts password…(and easiest for them if they are teamviewing or have a virus on your account…
[/quote]
You do realize that it’s reversable anyway, right?[/quote]
Also, I am only doing this for learning java, so that does not matter to me atm.

Read full topic

item.description:
@matzie wrote:

http://download.oracle.com/javase/1.4.2/docs/api/java/io/File.html

should probably find that useful =] its a break down of the File method. tells you all of the dealies it can do and what the return types are, and what the basic purpose of it is (in n3rd sp33k)

item.title: Player Saves in my Java game
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Native^, post:16, topic:416588”]If it is your first Java program, and if you are not that experienced, and have no fucking idea what serialization is. You should just store the data in a simple txt file.

Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in) BufferedWriter out = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("FILENAME.txt"); String name = scan.nextLine(); out.write(name); out.close(); [/quote]
I did finish my program, but I decided not to go with player saves, I will be making a game soon, and it will consist of player saves, so thank you for the help.

Read full topic

item.title: Player Saves in my Java game
item.dc:creator: @Native1 Native^
item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

If it is your first Java program, and if you are not that experienced, and have no fucking idea what serialization is. You should just store the data in a simple txt file.

       Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in)
       BufferedWriter out = new BufferedWriter(new FileWriter("FILENAME.txt");
       String name = scan.nextLine();
       out.write(name);
       out.close();

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Arrav Arrav
item.description:
@Arrav wrote:

MediaFire

CharSaveLoad.rar

MediaFire is a simple to use free service that lets you put all your photos, documents, music, and video in a single place so you can access them anywhere and share them everywhere.

I made a packaged IO datainput/outputstream save and load, just in the download, no virus’s no exe files…

item.title: Player Saves in my Java game
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

In your channel handler you would just add the saving (for logout).


package org.arsenal.net;

import java.net.InetSocketAddress;
import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger;
import java.util.logging.Logger;

import org.arsenal.net.packet.Packet;
import org.arsenal.net.packet.PacketManager;
import org.arsenal.util.settings.NetworkSettings;
import org.arsenal.world.World;
import org.jboss.netty.channel.ChannelEvent;
import org.jboss.netty.channel.ChannelHandlerContext;
import org.jboss.netty.channel.ChannelStateEvent;
import org.jboss.netty.channel.ExceptionEvent;
import org.jboss.netty.channel.MessageEvent;
import org.jboss.netty.channel.SimpleChannelHandler;
import org.jboss.netty.util.internal.ConcurrentHashMap;

public class ArsenalChannelHandler extends SimpleChannelHandler {

	Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(ArsenalChannelHandler.class.getName());
	
	//private ConcurrentHashMap<String, AtomicInteger> activeConnections;
	
	public void handleUpstream(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, ChannelEvent e) throws Exception {
		if(e instanceof ChannelStateEvent) {
			logger.info("Channel state changed: "+e);
		}
		super.handleUpstream(ctx, e);
	}
	
	public void handleDownstream(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, ChannelEvent e) throws Exception {
		if(e instanceof MessageEvent) {
			logger.info("Writing: "+e);
		}
		super.handleDownstream(ctx, e);
	}
	
	public void channelConnected(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, ChannelStateEvent e) throws Exception {
		/*InetSocketAddress address = (InetSocketAddress) ctx.getChannel().getRemoteAddress();
		AtomicInteger amount = activeConnections.putIfAbsent(address.getAddress().getHostAddress(), new AtomicInteger(1));
		if(amount == null)
			return;
		amount.incrementAndGet();
		if(amount.get() > NetworkSettings.max_connections) {
			logger.info("Connection Limit Reached for: "+address.getAddress().getHostAddress());
			ctx.getChannel().close();
			return;
		}
		super.channelConnected(ctx, e);*/
		World.addSession(ctx.getChannel());
	}
	
	public void channelDisconnected(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, ChannelStateEvent e) throws Exception {
		/*InetSocketAddress address = (InetSocketAddress) ctx.getChannel().getRemoteAddress();
		AtomicInteger amount = activeConnections.get(address.getAddress().getHostAddress());
		if(amount.get() > 1)
			amount.decrementAndGet();
		else
			logger.info("Connection Discconnected: "+address.getAddress().getHostAddress());
			activeConnections.remove(address.getAddress().getHostAddress());
		super.channelDisconnected(ctx, e);*/
		World.removeSession(ctx.getChannel());
	}
	
	public void messageReceived(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, MessageEvent e) throws Exception {
		Packet packet = (Packet) e.getMessage();
		PacketManager.addQueuedPacket(packet);
	}
	
	public void exceptionCaught(ChannelHandlerContext ctx, ExceptionEvent e) throws Exception {
		//super.exceptionCaught(ctx, e);
	}
	

}

You would most likely either want to save w/ xml or using binary. But since you are just getting started, just experiment with writing and loading from a text file for now.

Read full topic

@pk2play wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:3, topic:416588”][quote author=sp11k3t3ht3rd link=topic=518481.msg3767899#msg3767899 date=1317416072]

Hello, right now I am making my first Java program, it is in cmd and its basically a Math game, but here is my question, I want to ask what the players name is and then save it according to what he enters, but idk how I would start, I have the class PlayerSaves made but I’m not entirely sure what to do… If you could explain to me how I should start this please let me know.

If your making your first Java program its probably best to stay away from File I/O until your ready.
[/quote]
I have made other games before, but this is my first real game, like it actually has a meaning and objective, I have looked at the playersaves class in some PI servers I have on my computer, but I can’t figure out what to do to make my own…[/quote]
Lol. Why PI? Look in like a clean hyperion or something.
